abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Forest Development
            Project for Romania were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            substantial, Bank performance was satisfactory, and Borrower
            performance was also satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: agreeing on the structure and development of new
            information management systems for the forest sector,
            programming the software, and instituting the proper use of
            those new systems can take considerable time. At appraisal,
            very few cost-effective systems existed. For future Forest
            Management Information and Monitoring System (FMIMS)
            developments, off-the-shelf systems are now available at
            reasonable costs. In recent years, the Bank has been
            hesitant to invest in forestry, and in particular, road
            activities because of heightened non-government organization
            (NGO) attention. Because of the generally good outcomes of
            this project, especially with access roads, and the strong
            environmental and social linkages, this positive experience
            could offer an important lesson for the Bank both in terms
            of how to engage NGOs in seeking a way forward, but also in
            addressing critical safeguards issues. A lesson emerging
            from the project is that small-scale forest owners may
            require initial incentives to form associations and grow,
            such as training and technical support, accessing financing
            through a revolving fund partially funded through member
            contributions, tapping new forest carbon funds, etc. It is
            important that at effectiveness, projects have made good
            progress to establish a robust monitoring and evaluation
            (M&E) system with a baseline, plus a program and format
            for regular collection of data on input/outputs, processes,
            institutional development, impacts and outcomes.

11559763.trustfund: TF026361-PHRD-ROMANIA FOREST DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM,TF040005-ROMANIA - FORESTRY DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM,TF040762-ROMANIA FOREST DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM,TF040922-ROMANIA: FORESTRY DEVELOPMENT PROJECT
11559763.majtheme: Rural development,Environment and natural resource management,Rule of law

abstracts.cdata!:
The Forest Development Project
            objectives will be: (i) to improve the management of state
            owned forests through capacity building and technical
            innovation for environmentally-sustainable and cost
            effective forest management, and (ii) to support the
            establishment of pilot systems for forest management among
            underserved private forest owners. The following are changes
            in the Forest Development Project: (i) the project
            development objectives will be modified to reduce the
            sector-wide scope of planned interventions; (ii) envisaged
            support for the establishment of the Forest Sector Business
            Information Center will be dropped; (iii) support will be
            provided to design a Forest Geographic Information System as
            part of the Forest Management Information and Monitoring
            System (FMIMS); the planned program of forest roads
            rehabilitation will be scaled back; and (iv) support for
            private forest owners will be shifted to focus on groups of
            private owners of the smallest forest holdings, who
            generally lack capacity or the means for achieving economies
            of scale in forest management. The project support increased
            productivity and competitiveness of forest industries,
            through establishing and operating a Forest Sector Business
            Information Center (ForsBIC); and build public support for
            sustainable forest management by implementing a public
            awareness program targeting key stakeholders with an
            emphasis on new private forest owners. The project support
            for the development of a single national standard for
            sustainable forest management is being dropped, to allow for
            a diversity of national standards development.

439180.trustfund: TF040922-ROMANIA: FORESTRY DEVELOPMENT PROJECT,TF040762-ROMANIA FOREST DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM,TF040005-ROMANIA - FORESTRY DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM,TF026361-PHRD-ROMANIA FOREST DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM

abstracts.cdata!:
The Forest Development Project will
            improve the environmentally sustainable management of the
            State and private forests, in an effort to increase benefits
            to the national, and rural economies, derived from the
            country's forest resources. To this end, project
            components will: 1) Establish new systems to ensure
            sustainable management of private forest lands, by
            strengthening the Department of Forests, specifically, the
            Forest Inspectorate and Support Service within the Ministry
            of Agriculture, Food and Forests (MAFF). Supervisory,
            regulatory, and monitoring activities in forest management,
            will be supported, as will the provision of extension, and
            advisory services. Furthermore, support will be provided for
            the development of national, and local associations of
            private forest owners, which includes assistance for
            business development plans, service delivery, and capacity
            building in financial, and procurement management. In
            addition, a national forest management information, and
            monitoring system will be established to integrate cadastre,
            forest inventory, and biodiversity data. 2) Mitigate the
            State's forests management restitution, and its
            consequences, by supporting reform, and strategic
            development of the National Forest Administration, and,
            through the rehabilitation, and extension of the forest road
            network. 3) Support the increased productivity, and
            competitiveness of forest industries, through the
            establishment of the Forest Sector Business Information
            Center, to coordinate, and assist timber, and related forest
            industries. 4) Build public support for sustainable forest
            management, through public awareness campaigns. 5) Support
            project management, and financial activities, and oversee
            monitoring and evaluation aspects.

2074106.trustfund: TF040922-ROMANIA: FORESTRY DEVELOPMENT PROJECT,TF040762-ROMANIA FOREST DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM,TF040005-ROMANIA - FORESTRY DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM,TF026361-PHRD-ROMANIA FOREST DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM

repnme.cdata!:
Romania - Forest Development Program
            Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental assessment for the
            Forest Development Project, examined the status, trends, and
            institutional capacity for forest management in Romania, and
            key issues of the National Forest Policy, and Strategy. It
            assessed the project environmental impacts and proposed
            mitigation measures. Although the project will have
            positive, beneficial impacts, there are aspects which could
            have negative environmental, and social consequences if
            mitigation is not implemented. Adverse environmental
            impacts, and mitigating measures are as follows.
            Institutional recommendations suggest capacity building -
            formal, and on-the-job training, public awareness, etc. - to
            ensure compliance with environmental policies, including the
            involvement of public-private partnerships, to support an
            enabling environment. The main concern is the Forest Roads
            component, which involves road construction and
            rehabilitation in the area: baseline conditions, site
            selection, and engineering design will be reviewed to
            minimize adversity. Also, poorly managed forestry harvests
            may be endangered by increased timber industry demand, if
            institutional capacity measures, and public-private
            partnerships do not exercise regulations, a risk greatest in
            the case of newly restituted forest lands. The update
            volumes clarify issues and incorporate recommendations
            raised by NGOs, detail information disclosure, further
            examine illegal harvesting, and expands on the reasons for
            rejecting alternative projects.
